titleStmt.title: A declaration of the representations of the officers of the Navy. Concerning the impeached members of Parliament, transported beyond the seas. With a charge against some officers, who had commissions to raise forces to disturbe the peace of the kingdome. Also the Kings Majesties protestation, sent by Collonell Whaley.

titleStmt.title: A declaration of the representations of the officers of the Navy. Concerning the impeached members of Parliament, transported beyond the seas. With a charge against some officers, who had commissions to raise forces to disturbe the peace of the kingdome. Also the Kings Majesties protestation, sent by Collonell Whaley.
titleStmt.author: Whalley, Edward, d. 1675? Letter sent from Col: Whalley.

notesStmt.note: "The Kings Majesties protestation" was also published as: Whalley, Edward. A letter sent from Col: Whaley (Wing W1528); it is a disavowal of: His Majesties declaration to all his loving subjects, concerning his gracious inclination for peace (Wing C2229).
Reproduction of the original in the British Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: A DECLARATION OF THE REPRESENTATIONS OF THE OFFICERS of the NAVY.
CONCERNING The Impeached Members of Parliament, Tran≈øported beyond the Seas.
WITH A Charge again≈øt ≈øome Officers, who had Commi≈øsions to rai≈øe Forces to di≈øturbe the peace of the Kingdome.
ALSO The KINGS MAJESTIES PROTESTATION, Sent by Collonell WHALEY.
Printed at London by Robert Ibbit≈øon, 1647.

div.head: A Declaration of the Repre≈øentations of the Officers of the NAVY, Concerning the Impeached Members of Parliament Tran≈øported beyond the Seas.
div.p: A Diurnall came to our hands on Munday Augu≈øt 16. which hath a pa≈ø≈øage, as we apprehend it, that hath done us un≈øufferable wrong, we ble≈ø≈øe God, our wayes are open to him that knows our Innocency: And to Vindicate our ≈øelves, we have upon ≈øerious thoughts, not to adde to the ≈øad differences of the times, VVe had rather ≈øuffer quietly; but however we de≈øire to cleare our ≈øelves, to tho≈øe who are our friends, of tho≈øe ≈øcandalls which ≈øo much tend to the prejudice of us.

Tho≈øe Gentlemen are now aboard, who have ≈øeen and heard the Truth, and will no que≈øtion ≈øatisfie accordingly, when they returne: In the meane time we ≈øhall faithfully, as in Gods pre≈øence certifie the Truth.

The Members five of them tooke Bark at a Town by Quinborrough: Gave one Green 10 li. in hand, and were to give him 10 li. more at their Landing at Callis, and to ≈øecure his Barque out and in at 60 li. Upon which he having received the money, put another to ≈øaile in her as Ma≈øter; him≈øelfe went and got a VVarrant, ≈øaying the Members were gone without his con≈øent in his Barque: And with his VVarrant came to Fever≈øham, & there told the Inhabitants that ≈øome Parliament men were gone away with 16 Che≈øts and Portmantles full of Trea≈øure: upon which one Lamming, Ma≈øter of a Doger-boat cau≈øed Drums to beat, thinking to gain the money, and came after them, they taking in a Pilate here, he came by Captain Pacy, Capt. of a ≈ømall frigot, and told him that ≈øome Parliament men were run away with a great deale of trea≈øure: Upon which Captain Pacy let ≈ølip his Anchors, ≈øet Saile & made after them, and the Doger-boat never came neer them: but Capt. Pacy ≈øhooting one ≈øhot, they came in to him, & he brought them into the Downes: Sir Philip Stapleton very ≈øick of a flux (who ≈øince is dead of the
≈øickne≈ø≈øe at Callice:) They lay aboard us all night. The Vice-admirall ≈øent Capt. Lamming, for Mr. Green, to ≈øee what they had to ≈øhew for their leaving the Kingdome, and to ≈øee if they had any thing again≈øt them: but they not returning till a ‚Ä¶
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ Clock next day, he judging they were a≈øhamed of making ≈øuch an untrue ≈øtory, be called a Councell of Warr: and there they produced their ≈øeverall, pa≈ø≈øes, Dated two dayes before, grounded on an Order of the Hou≈øe of Commons upon their fir≈øt Impeachment; which by the Councell of Warre was peru≈øed: and at la≈øt it was re≈øolved to ≈øend Sir George Askue, Capt Crawley, Capt Pacy, and Lieutenant Penro≈øe, and divers others, to ≈øearch their Ve≈ø≈øell, which was accordingly, and exactly done, to their very pockets, and there was not much found, (onely they had Bills of Exchange).

So the Viceadmirall and the Councell of Warre not daring, having no Order to the contrary, and ≈øeeing Mr. Speakers Pa≈ø≈øe ≈øo lately Dated, did di≈ømi≈ø≈øe them: in their little Ve≈ø≈øell to pa≈ø≈øe.

About two houres after their di≈ømi≈ø≈øion
comes Lamming and Green,: and the Vice-admirall being at Dinner ≈øent for them in: Saw a VVarrant from the Captain of the Block-hou≈øe, Directed To all Con≈øtables, &c. He asked them which they thought would mo≈øt direct him to act by? a private Captains VVarrant, or an Order of both Hou≈øes of Parliament, and Pa≈ø≈øes under the Speakers hand? And that he was accountable for what he had done to both Hou≈øes.
He al≈øo ≈øent Major Keme to intreat Collonell Twa≈øelltons Trooper to come in and drink a gla≈ø≈øe of Wine, which he did: and we referre to him, if he had an uncivill word aboard.

Onely Major. Keme told Capt. Lamming, were he in the Army of the Councell of Warre, he would Vote him to be hanged, and he gave him this rea≈øon, that he knew he had a Commi≈ø≈øion in his pocket, ≈øigned by ≈øome of tho≈øe Members to rai≈øe a Company of Sea-men, to oppo≈øe the Army, and that he had received ten pounds to that purpo≈øe.

His Commi≈ø≈øion he ≈øhewed the Vice-Admirall
and as aboard in Parchment, and this was all the reviling language.

Then for Threatning; this we know, that he hath been out in a Dogerboate all the Summer: And hath when he ≈øhould have kept Sea, been lying a Shoare at Shoarum, Ha≈øtings, &c. Drinking drunk and hath abu≈øed, and had not the Viz-admirall found out his Knavery have cheated the State; upon which he ≈øent him in. VVe as divers Captaines and other Officers, and Chaplins that ≈øtood by to the number of one hundred can te≈øtify. And God is our record it is truth: And further I can a≈ø≈øure this.
1 That Collo Hollis was not there then as is reported, but Sir William Waller, Sir Phillip Stapleton, Sir John Clotworthy, Sir William Lewis, and Col: Long.
2 That Captaine Lamming is only Pot-valient, preferred from ≈ølavery in Argeire to be Ma≈øter of a Doger-boatc la≈øt yeere, and he nor any with them ever fired a Musket.
3 That the di≈ømi≈ø≈øion was not by the Viz-Admirall but by a cleare voce of a Councell of War.

4 That we neither reviled him nor threatned
him for that Act, Major Keme tould him he having ≈øuch a Commi≈øsion about him he might be hanged for beating up Drummer in the Country without other order.

closer.signed: Signed by the appointment of the Officers of the Navy.
closer.dateline: From Aboard the St. Andrew Admirall in the Downes, Aug. 26. 1647.

div.p: THere is a Paper of the 27 in≈øtant, (Intituled His Maje≈øties Declaration) made publick, it is patronized upon the King, but I a≈ø≈øure you His Maje≈øty is much abu≈øed in it: he hath many time to my ≈øelf and others, expre≈ø≈øed, not onely his di≈ø-avowing, but utter di≈ølike of it; at fir≈øt it ≈øomething troubled him, but is being ≈øo unlike any thing of his, and ≈øo contrary to his known intentions, be was confident it would not gain credence with any; yet ≈øince, hearing that divers both in City and Country, and Army, were ≈øo fondly credulous as to deem it to be His Maje≈øties, and ≈øo were much offended at it, it was the Kings Command I ≈øhould certifie my friends how extremely he is wronged, and truely Sir, you would doe the King but right, and di≈øcharge I conceive no more then your own duty to indevour the finding out the Author, and making him exemplary, and I am confident the King expects ≈øo much Ju≈øtice therein.

Here is little newes in Court more then this, that the King ye≈øterday was a hunting in New Parke, killed a Stag and a Buck, afterwards dined at Syon, ≈øtayed three or foure houres with his Children, and then returned to Hampton, where there is great re≈øort of all ≈øorts of people to him, but not ≈øo many Cavaliers as is reported, it is confe≈ø≈øed, no Gentleman is debarred the liberty of ki≈ø≈øing the Kings, hand, yet no ≈øtranger ≈øtayes tong, we have fre≈øh and fre≈øh appearances, the faces which appeare in the morning, you ≈øeldome ≈øee in the afternoone; at the farthe≈øt, but the next day. The Lord Conoway hath taken his leave of the Court for pre≈øent, I have no more to acquaint you with; I ≈øhall only again mind you, that to vindicate the King by di≈øcovering and puni≈øhing the Libeller, cannot but give great ≈øatisfaction to his Maje≈øty.
